comments.diffHunk:
@@ -86,7 +86,7 @@ def test_raw_and_probability_prediction(self):
         expected_rawPrediction = [-11.6081922998, -8.15827998691, 22.17757045]
         self.assertTrue(result.prediction, expected_prediction)
         self.assertTrue(np.allclose(result.probability, expected_probability, atol=1E-4))
-        self.assertTrue(np.allclose(result.rawPrediction, expected_rawPrediction, atol=1E-4))
+        self.assertTrue(np.allclose(result.rawPrediction, expected_rawPrediction, atol=1))

@@ -86,7 +86,7 @@ def test_raw_and_probability_prediction(self):
         expected_rawPrediction = [-11.6081922998, -8.15827998691, 22.17757045]
         self.assertTrue(result.prediction, expected_prediction)
         self.assertTrue(np.allclose(result.probability, expected_probability, atol=1E-4))
-        self.assertTrue(np.allclose(result.rawPrediction, expected_rawPrediction, atol=1E-4))
+        self.assertTrue(np.allclose(result.rawPrediction, expected_rawPrediction, atol=1))

comments.body: I'm not sure where the difference comes from, but it could be subtle differences in randomization or something across the JDKs. If these two tests are the only ones that vary, I think we're OK. I agree with loosening the bound here as these are log-odds, and I suspect the test values were picked just because it's what some previous run spit out (that is, it's too specific)

         expected_rawPrediction = [-11.6081922998, -8.15827998691, 22.17757045]
         self.assertTrue(result.prediction, expected_prediction)
         self.assertTrue(np.allclose(result.probability, expected_probability, atol=1E-4))
-        self.assertTrue(np.allclose(result.rawPrediction, expected_rawPrediction, atol=1E-4))
+        self.assertTrue(np.allclose(result.rawPrediction, expected_rawPrediction, atol=1))
